file_metadata.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]
file_metadata.title: US 2012O295.346A1

chunks.text: This invention details methods for modulating cell behavior, specifically proliferation, differentiation, and migration, by manipulating membrane potential through endogenous channel proteins. It also describes methods for identifying "instructor cells" that influence other cells' behavior and for discovering therapeutic agents to promote or inhibit these processes, including tissue regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Methods are presented for controlling cell behavior by modulating membrane potential via endogenous channels, identifying instructor cells, and finding therapeutic agents for tissue regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]

chunks.text: The challenge of regenerating complex tissues and organs is a central focus of biomedicine, driven by both clinical needs and the fundamental biological interest in self-repair.  Current research aims to understand the intricate processes of differentiation and regeneration to address degenerative diseases and injuries.
chunks.chunk_summary: Regenerative medicine seeks to understand the complex processes of tissue regeneration and development for clinical applications and to address diseases and injuries.
chunks.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]

chunks.text: The invention centers on modulating membrane potential to control cell proliferation, differentiation, and migration. One method involves using macrocyclic lactones to alter membrane potential through endogenous ligand-gated channels, thereby promoting tissue regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: The invention uses membrane potential modulation, including via macrocyclic lactones acting on endogenous channels, to control cell behavior and promote tissue regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]

chunks.text: A method for identifying instructor cells involves identifying endogenously expressed ligand-gated channels, altering membrane potential through these channels, and observing resulting phenotypes to determine the cell's influence on other cells' proliferation, differentiation, or migration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Instructor cells are identified by observing phenotypic changes in other cells after manipulating the candidate instructor cell's membrane potential through specific ligand-gated channels.
chunks.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]

chunks.text: This invention leverages endogenous ion channels and pumps to modulate cell behavior, unlike methods relying on heterologous protein expression.  By using agents like ivermectin to open channels like GlyCl and adjusting extracellular chloride concentration, membrane potential can be controlled to influence proliferation, differentiation, migration, neural outgrowth, and regeneration.
chunks.chunk_summary: The invention utilizes endogenous channels and modulates extracellular ion concentrations to control membrane potential and influence various cellular processes.
chunks.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]

chunks.text: The invention describes modulating membrane potential in either "instructor cells" to influence "subject cells" or directly in progenitor cells to control their behavior.  Fine-tuning membrane potential can promote or inhibit these processes, with depolarization generally promoting and hyperpolarization/repolarization inhibiting proliferation.
chunks.topic: Instructor cell and progenitor cell modulation
chunks.chunk_summary: The invention targets membrane potential modulation in both instructor cells (to indirectly affect other cells) and progenitor cells (for direct control), with depolarization promoting and hyper/repolarization inhibiting proliferation.
chunks.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]

chunks.text: "Instructor cells" are identified as a key element in tissue regeneration, influencing other cells' behavior non-cell-autonomously.  These cells are marked by specific endogenous ion channel expression, and modulating ion flux through these channels triggers their influence on other cells, even distant ones.  This approach also offers a novel way to inhibit proliferation, differentiation, and migration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Instructor cells, identifiable by unique ion channel expression, play a crucial role in tissue regeneration by influencing other cells' behavior, even at a distance, and offer a new approach to inhibiting cell processes.
chunks.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]

chunks.text: The invention provides a method for identifying instructor cells by detecting GlyCl channel expression.  Experiments demonstrate that modulating GlyCl channel activity with ivermectin affects melanocyte development, suggesting that cells expressing GlyCl act as instructor cells for melanocyte lineage.  Other ion channels may mark different instructor cell populations influencing other cell types.
chunks.chunk_summary: GlyCl channel expression identifies a population of instructor cells that influence melanocyte development, and other ion channels may mark instructor cells for different lineages.
chunks.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]

chunks.text: The method for identifying instructor cells involves screening for endogenous channel expression, modulating membrane potential through these channels with specific agents, and observing the resulting phenotypes in target cells. This allows for identifying agents that can promote or inhibit proliferation, differentiation, and regeneration of specific tissues with high specificity.
chunks.topic: Instructor cell identification and therapeutic agents
chunks.chunk_summary: By screening for channel expression and observing phenotypic effects of membrane potential modulation, the method identifies instructor cells and potential therapeutic agents for tissue regeneration with high specificity.
chunks.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]

chunks.text: Macrocyclic lactones, like ivermectin, are identified as agents for modulating membrane potential and cell behavior.  Nucleic acid approaches, including antisense oligonucleotides, ribozymes, and RNAi constructs, are also described for modulating channel expression and thus membrane potential.
chunks.chunk_summary: Macrocyclic lactones and nucleic acid-based approaches (antisense, ribozymes, RNAi) are described as tools for modulating membrane potential and cell behavior by targeting ion channels.
chunks.authors: ["US 2012O295.346A1", "(19) United States", "(43) Pub. Date: Nov. 22", "2012", "Related U.S. Application Data", "MODULATING MEMBRANE POTENTIAL TO", "(60) Provisional application No. 61/227", "708", "filed on Jul.", "INFLUENCE CELL BE HAVOR"]

chunks.text: The methods can be applied to cells from a wide range of organisms, including flatworms, amphibians, fish, reptiles, birds, and mammals, at various developmental stages.  The choice of model system depends on the specific research question and available tools, with examples like zebrafish, Xenopus, planaria, and C. elegans highlighted for their specific advantages.
chunks.chunk_summary: The methods are applicable to a broad range of organisms and developmental stages, with specific model systems like zebrafish, Xenopus, planaria, and C. elegans offering unique advantages for studying cell behavior and regeneration.
